</div></div><div><div><h3>âš¡ï¸Update: American Tire Distributors Inc.âš¡ï¸ </h3><div><figure><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/4498cff1-9c62-4c86-b1d5-3cf35c21bdbc?j=eyJ1IjoiOW95azAifQ.3I-y5PDezjo-i0ls31AGTIH4E8sNNl31puiktHvNIm8"><img src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_172,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F0a11acdf-664e-443c-8d67-9a38ae9fc59e_172x74.png"></a></figure></div><p><span>Youâ€™ll recall that </span><strong>American Tire Distributors Inc.</strong><span> and 12 of its affiliates (collectively, the â€œdebtorsâ€) filed chapter 11 cases redux in the District of Delaware (</span><strong>Judge Goldblatt</strong><span>) back on October 22, 2024, which we recently covered:</span></p><div><div><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/91bba6d9-9bf2-452f-817b-00c482932b72?j=eyJ1IjoiOW95azAifQ.3I-y5PDezjo-i0ls31AGTIH4E8sNNl31puiktHvNIm8"><picture><source><img src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_140,h_140,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep,g_auto/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fc06610bb-e022-46a4-9034-754ed7ed7196_500x500.gif"></source></picture></a></div><h4><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/91bba6d9-9bf2-452f-817b-00c482932b72?j=eyJ1IjoiOW95azAifQ.3I-y5PDezjo-i0ls31AGTIH4E8sNNl31puiktHvNIm8">ğŸ’¥New Chapter 22 Bankruptcy - American Tire Distributors Inc.ğŸ’¥</a></h4><div>Oct 29</div><span>Read full story</span></div><p><span>The debtors filed their cases â€œ</span><em>...with a line of sight to successfully consummate a going concern sale</em><span>â€ with a bit more than $30mm in cash on hand and an expectation to burn another $95mm of liquidity during the first 13 weeks of the cases.</span><span>Â¹</span><span> At risk of stating the obvious, the debtors needed a beefy DIP to fund the process, and an ad hoc group of DIP term lenders (the â€œDIP Term Lendersâ€)</span><span>Â²</span><span> was more than willing to graciously lend a hand â€” and by â€œgraciously lend a hand,â€ we mean (i) pony up $250mm in new money (with $125mm available during the interim period) (ii) </span><em>while also getting the benefit</em><span> of a roll up of approximately $75mm in 2024 Delayed Draw FILO Loans (iii) </span><em>and</em><span> $750mm (of $975mm) of prepetition term loans on a </span><em>non-pro rata</em><span> basis. Significantly, the DIP Term Lenders hold 100% of the 2024 Delayed Draw FILO Loans and approximately 90% of the prepetition term loans.</span></p><p><span>As our readers undoubtedly remember, way back in June â€˜20, </span><strong>Serta Simmons Bedding LLC</strong><span> (â€œSSBâ€) attempted something similar in an out of court transaction and closed a â€œ</span><em>liability management exercise</em><span>â€ that allowed a subset of its lenders to both infuse new capital into SSB and roll up certain of those lendersâ€™ existing debt obligations into new â€œ</span><em>super priority obligations</em><span>â€ that primed the other lenders in the same facility â€” in other words, those other non-participating lenders would be left holding the bag if (read: when) the transaction didnâ€™t work and SSB found itself in a formal in-court restructuring proceeding.</span><span>Â³</span><sup> </sup><span>Shocking no one, the transaction precipitated a significant amount of litigation, both prior to and during SSBâ€™s bankruptcy, and became synonymous with SSB itself â€” â€œuptierâ€ and â€œSertaâ€ are used interchangeably to describe this kind of priming transaction generally. Following similar transactions by other companies and ever-more fallout, lenders started contracting around these issues, requiring, for example, consent from all lenders to subordinate a credit facilityâ€™s existing debt to a new tranche (aka a â€œSerta blockerâ€) or to provide for a non-pro rata distribution. However, an exception to the Serta blocker also developed where, in the context of DIP financing specifically, unanimous lender consent wasnâ€™t necessary.</span><span>â´</span></p><p><span>Turning back to our debtors, that exception and its interplay with the prepetition term loan facilityâ€™s pro-rata paydown requirements, which are not referenced in the exception, are at the heart of a dispute thatâ€™s since arisen in the debtorsâ€™ bankruptcy. While the first day hearing proceeded unremarkably,</span><span>âµ</span><span> the following weeks got a lot more interesting: an ad hoc group representing losers â€¦ uh, we mean â€¦ â€œexcluded lendersâ€ (the â€œExcluded Lendersâ€), holding about 7.6% of the debt under the prepetition term loan facility and none too thrilled by being excluded from the party and the resulting prospect of a non-pro rata roll-up in which they wouldnâ€™t be participating, appeared and immediately started lobbing grenades at the DIP.</span><span>â¶</span></p><div><figure><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/6fddfa32-3523-460d-b847-16900ee08568?j=eyJ1IjoiOW95azAifQ.3I-y5PDezjo-i0ls31AGTIH4E8sNNl31puiktHvNIm8"><img src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_480,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_lossy/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F56cf084f-8c3d-433e-9090-51a50bb7fb1c_480x270.gif"></a><figcaption>Source: GIPHY. The Excluded Lenders on their way to court.</figcaption></figure></div><p><span>Boiled down, their argument was simple: the roll-up of the prepetition term loans under the DIP violated the prepetition term loan agreementâ€™s pro-rata distribution rules â€” that is, under that agreement, each lender is entitled to its ratable slice of amounts received on account of the prepetition term loans and to permit otherwise, including as part of a roll-up, would violate those rules.</span><span>â·</span><span> But they had a simple solution: cut them into the deal and allow them to fully participate in the DIP, extravagant fees and all.</span><span>â¸</span></p><div><figure><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/8e432367-c6b6-4830-a352-50beb1e179cd?j=eyJ1IjoiOW95azAifQ.3I-y5PDezjo-i0ls31AGTIH4E8sNNl31puiktHvNIm8"><img src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_480,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_lossy/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F5f41a484-7670-4967-a19f-e5b3b0c9e608_480x270.gif"></a><figcaption>Source:
